author: pbritt
title: New Intel-Powered Pocketable Verifone Device Meets Needs of Multi-Line Retailers
text:
Posted by pbritt on Sep 1st, 2015 in Featured Stories , Mobile Payments Conference | 0 comments 
Intel, Aava Mobile and Verifone partnered together to launch a pocketable, rugged POS device designed to facilitate mPOS transactions, Michelle Tinsley, general manager, personal solutions division at Intel, told the audience today at the Mobile Payments Conference in Chicago today. 
According to the press release jointly issued by the companies, the solution is based on Verifone’s device and operating system (OS)-agnostic mPOS terminal integrated with Aava Mobile’s rugged handheld tablet PC, which is powered by the Intel® Atom™ processor. 
Widespread mPOS adoption among multi-lane retailers is lagging due to limited flexibility typically associated with mPOS technology as well as its inability to seamlessly integrate with popular enterprise back-end systems. Most mPOS terminals only support a limited number of operating systems (OS) and tablet and smartphone form factors, requiring retailers to purchase new technology whenever they upgrade their mobile devices. 
The Verifone e355 mPOS terminal is agnostic to smartphone and tablet form factors and supports all major OS options, including Android, iOS and Windows—enabling retailers to make long-term investments in mPOS, at a much lower cost of ownership. 
Multi-lane retailers have substantially invested in Windows-based back-end systems to support critical workflows across their entire enterprise. 
The latest device continues the advancement of payments, which Tinsley described as a multi-decade journey that started with self-checkout 15 years ago, then payments through a mobile device about five years ago. Intel reports that mPOS transactions grew by 300 percent between 2013 and 2014. 
The pocketable device is designed to work in those locations where the existing mPOS devices aren’t meeting the merchants’ needs, according to Tinsley. “Different use cases require different types of devices.” 
Those use cases will continue to evolve, so Tinsley says payment hardware will continue to evolve as well. Share this:
